official-title.#text:
To amend the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to establish within the Environmental Protection
			 Agency a Columbia River Basin Restoration Program.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on the

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Columbia River Basin Restoration Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Columbia River Basin Restoration Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds that—

text.#text: the Columbia River is the largest river in the Pacific Northwest by volume;

the river is 1,253 miles long, with a drainage basin that includes 259,000 square miles, extending
			 to 7 States and British Columbia, Canada, and including all or part of—
multiple national parks;
components of the National Wilderness Preservation System;
National Monuments;
National Scenic Areas;
National Recreation Areas;
other areas managed for conservation; and
multiple tribal reservations and over 45,000,000 acres of tribally comanaged land;

quote.#tail:
) provide significant ecological and economic benefits to the Pacific Northwest and the entire
			 United States;

text.#text: the Columbia River Basin and associated tributaries (referred to in this Act as the

traditionally, the Basin includes more than 6,000,000 acres of irrigated agricultural land and
			 produces more hydroelectric power than any other North American river;
the Basin—

historically constituted the largest salmon-producing river system in the world, with annual
			 returns peaking at as many as 16,000,000 fish; and
as of the date of enactment of this Act—
supports economically important commercial and recreational fisheries;
supports treaty tribal fisheries;

is home to numerous species of salmonids, including steelhead, bull trout, and Kootenai white
			 sturgeon, that are listed as threatened species or endangered species
			 under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and

text.#text:
is a cultural and historical resource and provides sports and recreation opportunities for millions
			 annually;

toxics are present throughout the Columbia River Basin that are harmful to humans, fish, and
			 wildlife;
studies have shown that Columbia River fish contain a wide array of contaminants;

a fish consumption survey in the Columbia River Basin showed that tribal members were eating 6 to
			 11 times more fish than the estimated national average;
in 1995, the lower river and estuary was designated an

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
			 because of degradation and contamination in the lower river, lack of
			 structure to coordinate programs and policies, significance of the lower
			 river to survival of species throughout the basin, and the importance the
			 lower river to the economic viability of the region; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 320 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
named the Columbia River Basin 1
			 of the 10 large aquatic ecosystems in the United States;

text.#text: in 2006, the

the Columbia River Basin is the only large aquatic ecosystem in the United States that does not
			 receive dedicated appropriations as a large aquatic ecosystem; and

the other 9 large aquatic ecosystems receive appropriations through the Geographic Programs Program

term.#tail: means the Columbia River Basin Restoration Program established under subsection (b)(1)(A).

text.#text: The term
The term
the Columbia River Basin Toxics Reduction Working Group established under subsection (c); and
with respect to the Lower Columbia River Estuary, the Estuary Partnership.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall establish within the

a Columbia River Basin
			 Restoration Program for the purposes of reducing toxic contamination and
			 cleaning up contaminated sites throughout the Columbia River Basin.

text.#text: The

The Program shall not modify any legal or regulatory authority or program in effect as of the date
			 of enactment of this section, including the roles of Federal agencies in
			 the Columbia River Basin.

build on the work and collaborative structure of the existing Columbia River Toxics Reduction
			 Working Group representing the Federal Government, State, tribal, and
			 local governments, industry, and nongovernmental organizations, which was
			 convened in 2005 to develop a collaborative toxic contamination reduction
			 approach for the Columbia River Basin;

in the Lower Columbia River Basin and Estuary, build on the work and collaborative structure of the
			 Estuary Partnership;

coordinate with other efforts, including activities of other Federal agencies in the Columbia River
			 Basin, to avoid duplicating activities or functions; and
not impede implementation of existing agreements or other recovery and mitigation programs.
The Program shall—

The Program shall consist of a collaborative stakeholder-based program for reducing toxic
			 contamination throughout the Columbia River Basin.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: The

assess trends in water quality and toxic contamination or toxics reduction, including trends that
			 affect uses of the water of the Columbia River Basin;

collect, characterize, and assess data on toxics and water quality to identify possible causes of
			 environmental problems;
provide the Working Group with data, analysis, reports, or other information;

provide technical assistance to the Working Group, and to State governments, tribal governments,
			 and local governments participating in the Working Group, to assist those
			 agencies and entities in—
developing updates to the Action Plan;
recommending and prioritizing projects and actions for the Action Plan; and

reviewing progress and effectiveness of projects and actions implemented, as well as cumulative
			 progress toward the goals of this section, and the Action Plan;

periodically update the Action Plan and the Estuary Plan as required by counsel, and ensure that
			 those plans, when considered together and in light of relevant plans
			 developed by other Federal or State agencies, form a coherent toxic
			 contamination reduction strategy for the Columbia River Basin;

track progress toward meeting the identified goals and objectives of the Action Plan by
			 coordinating and reporting environmental data related to the Action Plan
			 and the Estuary Plan and making the data and reports on the data available
			 to the public; and
provide grants in accordance with subsection (d) for projects that—
assist in—
eliminating or reducing pollution;
cleaning up contaminated sites;
improving water quality;
monitoring to evaluate trends;
reducing runoff;
protecting habitat; or
promoting citizen engagement or knowledge;
address the goals, tasks, or action items in the Action Plan or the Estuary Plan; and
are recommended by the Working Group to implement the Estuary Plan.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall establish a Columbia River Basin Toxics Reduction Working Group.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: under this subsection may decline membership.

text.#text: Membership in the Working Group shall be on a voluntary basis and any person invited by the
each State located in whole or in part within the Columbia River Basin;
the Governors of each State located in whole or in part with the Columbia River Basin;
each federally recognized Indian tribe in the Columbia River Basin;
local governments located in the Columbia River Basin;
industries operating in the Columbia River Basin that affect or could affect water quality;
electric, water, and wastewater utilities operating in the Columba River Basin;
private landowners in the Columbia River Basin;
soil and water conservation districts in the Columbia River Basin;
nongovernmental organizations that have a presence in the Columbia River Basin;
the general public in the Columbia River Basin; and
the Estuary Partnership.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall invite, at a minimum, representatives of—

text.#text: The
The Working Group shall include representatives from—
each State; and
each of the Lower, Middle, and Upper Basins of the Columbia River.
The Working Group shall—

participate in developing updates to the Action Plan, including by providing comments on the
			 updates;
recommend and prioritize projects and actions for the Action Plan; and

review the progress and effectiveness of projects and actions implemented, as well as cumulative
			 progress toward the goals of this section, and the Action Plan.

The Estuary Partnership shall perform the duties and fulfill the responsibilities of the Working
			 Group described in paragraph (4) as those duties and responsibilities
			 relate to the Lower Columbia River Estuary for such time as the Estuary
			 Partnership is the management conference for the Lower Columbia River
			 National Estuary Program under section 320.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

may
			 designate the new management conference to assume the duties and
			 responsibilities of the Working Group described in paragraph (4) as those
			 duties and responsibilities relate to the Lower Columbia River Estuary.

text.#text:
If the Estuary Partnership ceases to be the management conference for the Lower Columbia River
			 National Estuary Program under

The Estuary Plan shall function as the Action Plan for the Lower Columbia River Estuary for such
			 time as there is an Estuary Plan in place pursuant to

If the Estuary Partnership is removed from the National Estuary Program, the duties and
			 responsibilities for the lower 146 miles of the Columbia River pursuant to
			 this Act shall be incorporated into the duties of the Working Group.

shall establish a voluntary, competitive Columbia River Basin toxics program to
			 provide grants to State governments, tribal governments, regional water
			 pollution control agencies and entities, local government entities,
			 nongovernmental entities, or soil and water conservation districts to
			 develop or implement projects authorized under this section for the
			 purpose of implementing the Action Plan and the Estuary Plan.

shall not exceed 75 percent of the total cost of the project or activity; and

shall be made on condition that the non-Federal share of that total cost shall be provided from
